operation.definition: The ontologically primitive notion; operations generate objects as stable invariants, not performed on pre-existing objects.

substrate.definition: The continuous field capable of supporting operations; an active medium with coherence capacity, memory retention, and resistance to threading.

threading.definition: The act of performing operations on substrate, leaving traces (memory) and creating paths through configuration space; threading depth corresponds to operational accumulation.

configuration.definition: A possible arrangement of substrate after operations; temporary stabilities in ongoing operational processes, not static snapshots.

coherence.definition: The degree to which operational patterns reinforce rather than interfere; substrate's ability to maintain consistent threading patterns.

memory.definition: Accumulated operational history encoded in substrate; persistent structural changes from operations, not storage of information.

invariant.definition: What remains unchanged under specified operations; stable structures emerging from operational constraints.

teleology.definition: Directedness toward intended forms inherent in operational structure; forms are attractors satisfying coherence, stability, and efficiency constraints.

IOGT.definition: Composable operations induce intrinsic gradients of difficulty; forward construction and reverse reconstruction are generically asymmetric.

operational_gradient.definition: Intrinsic directional structure of substrate making some operations easier than others; cannot be eliminated, reflects fundamental asymmetries.

gradient_aligned.definition: Operations proceeding with (downhill along) the operational gradient; polynomial cost, includes evaluation and verification.

gradient_opposed.definition: Operations proceeding against (uphill) the operational gradient; exponential cost, includes search and inversion.

operational_potential.definition: Minimal effort to reach state x from initial state; V(x) = inf{C(w) | w(x₀) = x}.

operational_cost.definition: Effort/resources required to execute operation sequence; C: O* → ℝ≥0 satisfying monotonicity and subadditivity.

forward_construction.definition: Building output from input by applying operations; typically gradient-aligned with polynomial cost.

reverse_reconstruction.definition: Determining input from output by inverting operations; typically gradient-opposed with exponential cost.

composition_amplification.definition: Asymmetry magnifies under operational composition; ε-forward-easy can require exp(n)-reverse-hard.

IOT.definition: Exponential operational cost cannot be perfectly conserved across time-parallelism trade; overhead factor (1+c) is irreducible.

coordination_cost.definition: Extra operational overhead required to synchronize parallel branches; arises from substrate limitations.

branch_potential.definition: Information-theoretic measure of distinct computational branches; log₂(branch_count).
branch_potential.equation: H = log₂(N) where N = number of branches

irreducible_overhead.definition: Minimum unavoidable coordination cost in parallel operations; cannot be eliminated by algorithmic optimization.

attractor.definition: Stable configuration toward which operations converge; fixed points where f(x*) = x*.

fixed_point.definition: Configuration unchanged by operation; x* satisfying f(x*) = x*.

phi.definition: Golden ratio; fixed point of x = 1 + 1/x; self-similar growth ratio emerging from additive operations.

pi.definition: Ratio of circumference to diameter; operational cost of rotation; emerges from exp(iθ) periodicity.

e.definition: Natural base; rate at which operations compound continuously; fixed point of continuous growth.

i.definition: Imaginary unit; 90-degree rotation operator; represents orthogonal threading in perpendicular operational dimension.

Omega_p.definition: Prime-indexed attractor family; fixed point of x = 1 + 1/x^(p-1) for prime p; each prime generates unique depth.

threading_aggregate.definition: Operations compose by threading through previous results, creating nested coherence; mechanism stabilizing at fixed points.

number.definition: Operational invariant of counting and grouping operations; repeatable procedures yielding same structural pattern.

zero.definition: Additive identity; operation that changes nothing; configuration before any counting operation begins.

one.definition: Multiplicative identity; minimal threading; single operational step; unit by which all operations are measured.

prime.definition: Irreducible multiplicative atom; number divisible only by 1 and itself; fundamental building blocks of multiplication.

composite.definition: Product of primes; non-prime natural number greater than 1; factorizable into irreducible components.

addition.definition: Sequential threading; performing one operation after another; operational composition along single dimension.

multiplication.definition: Repeated threading; iterating an operation; operational iteration creating amplification.

exponentiation.definition: Iterated multiplication; operations on operations; meta-operational counting of iteration depth.

factorial.definition: Cascading multiplication; product of all threading operations up to n; measures permutation space size.

angular_entropy.definition: Shannon entropy of directional energy distribution in dyadic shell j; measures angular complexity of velocity field.

threading_deficit.definition: Energy locked in 3D noncoplanar triads; quantifies steepness of operational gradient for angular refinement.

dyadic_shell.definition: Fourier modes in frequency band {k: 2ʲ ≤ |k| < 2^(j+1)}; partitions frequency space by scale.

threading_subspace.definition: 2D plane perpendicular to wavevector k; incompressibility forces velocity modes into this reduced dimensional space.

incompressibility.definition: Constraint div(u) = 0 forcing energy to thread through 2D planes; provides geometric penalty preventing blowup.

viscous_dissipation.definition: Energy decay from viscosity ν; rate ~ν|k|² dominates deficit growth by factor 2^(4j) at shell j.

BKM_criterion.definition: Bounded vorticity gradients imply global regularity; operational geometry achieves this via bounded angular entropy.

point.definition: Minimal operational localization; configuration with zero extension; operational address in substrate space.

line.definition: One-dimensional threading path; configurations reachable by threading in single direction; operational trajectory.

plane.definition: Two-dimensional operational surface; configurations reachable by threading in two independent directions.

dimension.definition: Operational degrees of freedom; number of independent threading directions available.

distance.definition: Operational separation; minimum threading required to transform one configuration into another; measured in operational steps.

continuity.definition: Operational smoothness; arbitrarily small input changes produce arbitrarily small output changes; coherence preservation under infinitesimal threading.

derivative.definition: Rate of operational change; how fast threading produces new configurations; instantaneous threading velocity.

integral.definition: Accumulated operational effect; total structural change from continuous threading; sums infinitesimal operations.

limit.definition: Operational convergence; configuration approached as threading depth increases; asymptotic attractor of operational sequences.

symmetry.definition: Operational invariance under transformation; threading that leaves structure unchanged; operations that are their own inverse.

manifold.definition: Locally flat operational space appearing linear under small threading but curving globally; space where local operations compose into global structure.

topology.definition: Operational connectedness; properties preserved under continuous threading; studies structures surviving deformation without tearing.

mass.definition: Memory density; accumulated operational history in substrate region; quantifies threading retention.

energy.definition: Operational potential; capacity for future threading stored in current configuration; unexecuted operations.

momentum.definition: Directed operational potential; energy with preferred threading direction; vectored capacity for future operations.

force.definition: Coherence gradient; operational pressure from memory density differences; substrate's tendency toward operational equilibrium.

charge.definition: Operational polarity; sign of electromagnetic threading coupling; determines whether operations attract or repel.

spin.definition: Topological winding; rotational threading depth encoded in substrate structure; operational chirality.

time.definition: Threading depth; operational accumulation, not duration; counted in operations performed.

space.definition: Operational separation; distance measured in threading steps needed to connect configurations; metric of operational accessibility.

gravity.definition: Memory density gradient; operational flow toward regions of accumulated threading; substrate's response to mass concentration.

field.definition: Distributed operational potential; continuous mapping assigning operational capacity to every point; substrate property guiding threading.

algorithm.definition: Determinate operational sequence; specified path through configuration space guaranteed to terminate; reproducible threading procedure.

complexity.definition: Threading depth requirement; operational cost to reach result; time/space complexity measures steps/memory.

P.definition: Problems solvable by gradient-aligned operations; deterministic polynomial-time algorithms; forward construction class.

NP.definition: Problems verifiable in polynomial time; gradient-opposed search problems; reverse reconstruction class.

recursion.definition: Self-referential threading; operations invoking themselves as sub-operations; operational self-similarity.

iteration.definition: Repeated operational application; threading same operation multiple times; controlled operational repetition.

information.definition: Operational distinguishability; minimum threading required to differentiate states; operational content of memory.

entropy.definition: Operational uncertainty; logarithm of indistinguishable threading histories producing same macroscopic configuration; hidden operational degrees of freedom.

Turing_machine.definition: Minimal universal threader; simplest operational system capable of any computable threading sequence; defines algorithmic operations boundary.

set.definition: Collection defined by operational membership; predicate determining whether threading included a configuration; operational boundaries.

union.definition: Combining operational domains; configurations reachable by either operation A or B; operational aggregation.

intersection.definition: Overlapping operational domains; configurations reachable by both operations A and B; operational constraint satisfaction.

function.definition: Operational mapping; rule threading configurations from one domain into another; deterministic operation sequence.

domain.definition: Operational input space; configurations on which function can operate; where threading begins.

range.definition: Operational output space; configurations function can produce; where threading ends.

composition.definition: Sequential function application; threading one operation after another; (f∘g)(x) = f(g(x)).

frontier_problem.definition: Type A problem with low stability and disconnected approaches; needs new operations/dimensions.

bridge_problem.definition: Type B problem with moderate stability and emerging coherence; needs attractor connection.

stable_attractor_problem.definition: Type C problem with high stability and single framework; operate deeply within established structure.

axiom_boundary_problem.definition: Type D problem with 100+ years no progress; may be undecidable in current axiom system.

operational_depth.definition: Number of sequential threading operations performed; time as operational count, not duration.

operational_width.definition: Number of parallel threading branches; simultaneous operational possibilities; nondeterministic computation dimension.

operational_locality.definition: Constraint that operations directly thread only nearby substrate regions; non-local effects require mediated paths.

coherence_capacity.definition: Substrate's maximum ability to maintain consistent threading patterns; finite capacity limits instantiable mathematical structures.

coherence_threshold.definition: Critical operational complexity beyond which substrate cannot maintain consistent threading; quantum decoherence and computational intractability.

threading_rate.definition: Operations per unit substrate volume; different regions have different rates, perceived as field intensity variations.

reversible_operation.definition: Operation that can be exactly undone without information loss; all fundamental physical operations are reversible.

irreversible_operation.definition: Operation discarding information, increasing entropy; measurement, forgetting, thermalization; genuinely loses operational history.

configuration_space.definition: Space of all possible substrate configurations; each point represents distinct threading arrangement; operations are paths through this space.

operational_flow.definition: Natural direction operations follow due to gradient; geodesics in configuration space; efficient algorithms work with flow.

closure_forces_finiteness.definition: Finite closure implies finite components; seeking closure constrains system size.

density_freezing.definition: Constrained systems develop frozen densities; distributions stabilize under iteration (e.g., π(x) ~ x/ln(x)).

irreducibility_fundamental.definition: All structure equals composition of irreducibles; primes are mathematical atoms (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic).

absorption_drives_specialization.definition: Absorbing operations lead to stable-attractor stage; systems evolve toward absorbing states (e.g., 0 absorbs in ×).

resonance_creates_harmony.definition: Aligned constraints produce stability and beauty; mathematical beauty equals structural resonance.

periodic_obstruction_signals_incompatibi.definition: Cycles without convergence indicate fighting constraints; incompatibility manifests as non-termination.

succession_drives_evolution.definition: Mathematical structures evolve from exploratory to stable-attractor stages; closure requirements force expansion (ℕ→ℤ→ℚ→ℝ→ℂ).

attractors_are_invariant.definition: f(x*) = x* means x* is operational invariant; constants are operational equilibria, fixed points of iteration.

conservation_of_operational_potential.definition: Threading cost must equal or exceed increase in operational potential; energy/complexity cannot be created from nothing.

axiom_of_operational_priority.definition: Operations are ontologically prior to objects; objects emerge as stable invariants under repeated operations.

axiom_of_substrate_reality.definition: There exists a substrate capable of supporting operations with intrinsic properties constraining admissible operations.

axiom_of_finite_physical_realizability.definition: Physical substrates have finite coherence capacity, finite memory capacity, and finite operational rate.

axiom_of_teleological_constraints.definition: Operations are directed toward forms satisfying coherence, stability, efficiency, and beauty constraints; emergent structures are filtered by purposiveness.

axiom_of_geometric_emergence.definition: Spatial structure (distance, dimension, continuity) emerges from operational substrate threading, not pre-existing.

Intrinsic_Operational_Gradient_Theorem.definition: Every physically realizable computation admits intrinsic operational gradient satisfying non-degeneracy, information-theoretic scaling, irreducibility, and representation independence.

Plus_One_Theorem.definition: Addition of unity (+1) is the minimal non-trivial operational increment; generates natural numbers and their structure.

Unreachability_Principle.definition: Certain configurations are unreachable from given initial states by admissible operations; operational accessibility defines possibility.

global_regularity.definition: 3D Navier-Stokes equations admit global smooth solutions; incompressibility provides geometric penalty preventing blowup.

P_neq_NP.definition: P ≠ NP follows from IOGT; gradient-aligned (P) operations cannot reverse gradient-opposed (NP) exponential cost.

natural_numbers.definition: Generated by +1 operation from 0; exploratory stage of number system evolution.

integers.definition: ℕ closed under subtraction; includes negative threading (reverse operations).

rationals.definition: ℤ closed under division (except by 0); field of fractions; periodic decimal expansions.

reals.definition: ℚ closed under limits; completion via Cauchy sequences or Dedekind cuts; continuous line.

complex_numbers.definition: ℝ ∪ {i} where i² = -1; algebraically closed; 2D operational plane.

algebraic_numbers.definition: Roots of polynomials with integer coefficients; countable; includes √2, φ.

transcendental_numbers.definition: Not algebraic; uncountable; transcend polynomial equations; includes π, e.

Fourier_mode.definition: Frequency component of field at wavevector k; Fourier transform decomposes fields into operational frequencies.

wavevector.definition: Spatial frequency vector; magnitude |k| is frequency scale, direction is orientation of oscillation.

frequency_cascade.definition: Energy transfer from large scales (low frequency) to small scales (high frequency); operational flow through scale space.

spectral_decomposition.definition: Breaking field into frequency components; reveals scale-by-scale operational structure.

triad.definition: Three-way interaction in Fourier space with k₁+k₂+k₃=0; noncoplanar triads maximize geometric penalty in 3D.

noncoplanar.definition: Three vectors not lying in same plane; volume |k₁·(k₂×k₃)| ≠ 0; essential for 3D energy transfer.

Leray_projector.definition: Projects vector fields onto divergence-free subspace; P_k(ξ) = ξ - k(k·ξ)/|k|².

enstrophy.definition: Integrated vorticity squared; |∇×u|² integrated over domain; measures rotation intensity.

blowup.definition: Solution becoming unbounded in finite time; singularity formation; operational geometry proves this cannot occur for 3D NS.

self_similarity.definition: Structure repeating at different scales; fractal property; operational patterns reproducing under scaling.

scale_invariance.definition: Properties unchanged under scaling transformations; no characteristic length; continuous symmetry.

criticality.definition: Phase transition point; balance between competing tendencies; operational equilibrium between growth and decay.

related_frameworks.category_theory: Studies composition of morphisms; operational geometry generalizes to substrate operations
related_frameworks.dynamical_systems: Studies iteration and attractors; operational geometry provides ontological foundation
related_frameworks.constructive_mathematics: Mathematics via explicit construction; aligns with operations-primary view
related_frameworks.process_philosophy: Reality as process not substance; operational geometry formalizes this mathematically
related_frameworks.information_theory: Quantifies distinguishability; operational interpretation as threading requirements

one_sentence_summary: Operational Geometry is a framework where operations are ontologically primary, mathematical objects emerge as stable attractors of iterative threading processes on substrate, and fundamental constants arise necessarily from fixed points in operational space.
